body: Social media has become a central part of daily life, especially among young people. While it offers opportunities for connection, self-expression, and learning, excessive use can negatively impact mental health. Constant exposure to carefully curated images and posts often leads to social comparison, feelings of inadequacy, and low self-esteem. Notifications and the pressure to stay â€œonlineâ€ can increase stress and anxiety, sometimes even affecting sleep quality. On the flip side, social media can also provide valuable mental health support through online communities, awareness campaigns, and access to resources. Striking a balanceâ€”using social media mindfully, setting boundaries, and seeking offline connectionsâ€”can help protect and promote positive mental well-being.

title: New Year, New me
body: I really wouldn't say going into a new year means you totally changing, like magic. It really just majorly focuses on your mentality. Personally, I think that a change in mindset later causes a change in the physical realm. So it doesn't mean that challenges won't be there. It doesn't mean that you won't feel bad, broken or hurt. All it means is that you're ready to embrace such comings in your life and handle them in a different way from the way you did. Additionally, change takes time. Get rid of the mentality that by you doing something today, means that at an instant everything is gonna change. Honestly, thinking that way, will make you lose hope, lose focus and short tempered. It's gonna take time to change, and this year may not be enough, and you might have to do it next year, or the year after that, but it's okay, just push on. Time isn't our major concern, is it? In the end, we wanna see improvement, whether small or big, it's still improvement. Lastly, avoid comparison, it's the killer of joy. Do things as you, don't look at how 'good' or "successful" this person's life is going while yours looks 'stagnant'.

Possibly you are like me, or this has happened to you. All I want to tell you is, firstly, what you are experiencing is totally normalâ€”donâ€™t beat yourself up about it like I did. Secondly, you can â€œfixâ€ it or resolve this issue, but from my experience, Iâ€™m not sure if that feeling ends completely (I mean, Iâ€™m only sixteen).

So here is what you can do. Though it may sound clichÃ© and all, trust meâ€”this is what worked for me. First, I journaled (Iâ€™ll dive deeper into this later). Second, I changed my mentalityâ€”the words I told myself.

Okay, so I journaled, and you may be asking, â€œOkay, Manuel, how did journaling help you? I mean, itâ€™s just writing your thoughts on a piece of paper. It doesnâ€™t really have any great impact, does it?â€ You see, the more you have thoughts that donâ€™t give you peaceâ€”thoughts that make you lose hope or feel lostâ€”and you keep them in your mind, the more youâ€™ll find yourself overthinking and feeling lost. So journaling takes these emotions out of your mind, because remember, emotions donâ€™t know whether theyâ€™ve been written on paper or not. So journaling saves your brain that stress.

Now, what I did next was change how I spoke to myself. Before, I used to tell myself, â€œYouâ€™re boring,â€ â€œYou need friends so that you donâ€™t get bored.â€ And honestly, you might think, â€œBut Manuel, theyâ€™re just wordsâ€”nothing much.â€ But words have such a great impact on who you are. Take this analogy of fresh water and salty water: drinking fresh water is more refreshing than drinking salty water. In this case, fresh water is positive, motivating words, while salty water is negative and derailing words. If you were to take salty water and water a plant, that plant would eventually die. Why? Itâ€™s not ideal for its growth. And if it were fresh water, it would be the other way aroundâ€”the plant would actually grow.

So in the same way, words are equally important, and they either make you grow or wither. So every day in the morning, I write positive words in my journal or say positive words to myself. At first, itâ€™s going to be really hard, and youâ€™ll feel resistance, but itâ€™s worth a shot. Right now, for me, I find it really easy to be positive and kind, although a few months ago it was the opposite.

In the end, these two processes helped me love myself and accept myself for who I am (though I still feel some resistance). But itâ€™s not that you wonâ€™t feel bad or lonelyâ€”you will. The only thing that matters is how you handle it. Donâ€™t give up; youâ€™re going to make it, okay? Have a good one aheadâ€¦ Byeeee, and make sure you keep on blooming ğŸ˜
